item.title: Rethinking learning outcomes

item.title: Silent transformation of urban ecology
item.description: ARTIFICIAL light at night has emerged as a pervasive and rapidly expanding environmental stressor, particularly in regions undergoing accelerated urbanisation. Once confined to limited urban cores, night-time illumination now extends far beyond city centres, reshaping landscapes, ecosystems and biological rhythms on a global scale. The increasing prevalence of......

item.title: Search for new language in politics
item.description: I AM not a politician, an academic, or a commentator. I am simply a civilian who has lived my entire life in Bangladesh, watching a political system that has rarely felt functional. Since my birth, I have not witnessed a stable, accountable model of governance that truly serves its people. Instead, what I have seen regardless of which party held power is a recurring cycle of......Bangladesh travel guides

item.title: Democracy begins with fearless vote
item.description: AS BANGLADESH moves closer to its 13th parliamentary election and the accompanying referendum, the public mood is not festive. It is anxious. Instead of the familiar rituals of democratic competition — rallies, debates, leaflets, slogans — the country is bracing for something darker. Media reports suggest that at least 24 districts are now considered at high risk......

item.title: Avoidable disasters continue because of criminal neglect
item.description: YET another death of a child from falling into a hole dug for a deep tube-well at Raozan in Chattogram exposes a criminal failure of the authorities to address a menace that has already claimed many lives. item.title: Nipah risk demands urgent vigilance
